Wouldn't it be much more effective if you offset the candle and kinked both ends the same way? That way one hole is an intake and the other is an outlet. The force of the intake will aid the force of the outlet in spinning the cork, and keeping the candle offset helps enforce the association by making one side of the loop warmer than the other.

Nice idea. It works even better when you bend the bottoms of the tube in the same direction. Because one sucks and the other blows. That way they don't try to cancel each other out.

Also, when you place the candle a bit more to the side of the bottom of the loop, then it heats up the side of the loop, which might help circulation a bit.

This is a vacuum engine. If you speed down and look at the water flow when its blue-dyed, the two exhausts never push together. Water first boils and the volume is expanded inside, that pushes out the water, at the same time water vapor cools down touching the cold parts of the metal tube which turns to water again. This expansion and cooling makes the move. Although its sometimes called a steam engine, there is no steam getting out.

The  pulsing is because the tube has to draw in more water after ejecting the heated water. The new water has to be heated and likewise ejected. As the water in the container would heat up from this over time, the time it takes to heat the newly drawn in water would decrease. There are ways to insure that water is drawn in from one side of the tube and ejected from the other. This would reduce the pulsing effect. One is by adjusting the position of the flame to one side of the loop, the other is to make one tube end longer than the other. This is how the cooling system on an old Model A Ford worked without a water pump, instead depending on the "percolator effect" to move the water from the engine to the radiator.

Try doing that but doing a water density engine.  As you heat up water it's density is lower than colder water.  So hot water will float up and cold water will sink.  So you could do the same experiment but this time no loop.  Make it an upside down U, then bend one leg so that it goes over the candle.  The water over the candle will heat up and become less dense.  Then it will flow up the tube causing the cold water to go down the other side of the tube.  The hot water will cool down in the tube at the top and be pushed down the cold leg while cold water replaces the hot water to get heated up and continue the cycle.  I would only bend the cold side of the U so that it will push the engine around.
